poem:
Title: "The Quiet Corners of our Cities"

In these low-traffic neighbourhoods, 
facades echo silent hymns.
Streetlights cast an eloquent language 
onto shadow-kissed pavements. 
Here, the world is slowed,
wreathed in silence, not vehicular hum.
Bereft of tangling controversy, Sunak finds,
birds replaced the horns
and in this slow turning,
we discover spaces are more popular 
when absent of speed,
Full of whispers,
each house, a stanza of tranquility.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Low-traffic neighbourhoods generally popular, report ordered by Sunak finds An official study of low-traffic neighbourhoods (LTNs) ordered by Rishi Sunak amid efforts to stop them being built has instead concluded they are generally popular and effective, with the report initially buried, the Guardian has learned. The long-delayed review by Department for Transport (DfT) officials was commissioned by the prime minister last July, as Sunak sought to capitalise on controversy about the schemes by promising drivers". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
